specs.Part #:
RTX 4060 VENTUS 2X BLACK 8G OC
GeForce RTX 4060 VENTUS 2X BLACK 8G OC
912-V516-004
V516-004R
G4060V2XB8C

comments: Bought it used and no issues so far.
Much better than I was expecting. It's pretty great for the price, I wish more games supported DLSS and frame gen though

I don't play games. I needed a GPU to speed up photo processing. Topaz AI needs 8 gigs of VRAM. It would not even run on my Windows 12700K without a GPU. With the 4060, I tested the same image that took over 30 minutes to render on a Macbook Pro M2 Pro with 16 GB Ram. On my new Windows build, it took only 12 minutes. It appears the rendering engine runs almost entirely on the GPU. The GPU is pegged at 100%. The CPU is cruising along well under 10%.
Fan runs at 0 rpm until needed and then is still basically silent. GPU only uses 115 watts max.
Great GPU, I know it gets hated on but it's not a bad GPU just a bad price, was luckily able to pick it up as a unwanted gift for 200e, ran great but fans can get a bit loud when under high load
Perfect for my use and 1080p gaming so I can't complain too much, just feels bad that its 8GB for the price.

The MSI Ventus cooler usually gets a bad rep, especially for the higher-end GPUs such as the 80 and 90 class, but I’ve experienced zero issues with this particular model. It’s got great aesthetics, and is well-suited for SFF builds and compact m/ATX cases.
At $300 USD, I think the RTX 4060 is a bit too expensive for what it is, given the 128-bit memory bus and 8 GB VRAM. For 1080p and even some games at 1440p, the performance is still pretty good, especially in tandem with DLSS, and it the GPU barely consumes power, so it runs super cool and quiet.
This video card is more than enough for any new video game if you are playing in 1080p and even 1440p. Stop fan mode allows it to be dead silent while idling.
I managed to get this to play 1440p on all of the games I play. I originally thought the 8GB would be a problem, but It's actually just fine!
Does what I expected. great 1080P performances at a reasonable cost. In Canada a RTX 4070 goes for 500 more dollars and depending on your gaming habits the premium can be unjustified.

I’m not one to defend nvidia (lookin at you, 5090 inferno,) but i honestly feel bad for the rtx 4060. At 150 watts of power draw (not even,) it’s extremely efficient. Also, while the generational gains aren’t great, as far as the 40 series lineup goes, it competes against Amd better than the 4070-80-90 do, atleast in my opinion.

name: Sapphire PULSE Radeon RX 9070 XT 16 GB Video Card
comments: Probably paid more for this card than I should have, but I didn't want to wait any longer and doubted prices would stabilize any time soon. This thing is beefy 3 slot card with an equally impressive cooler. I never saw my temps rise about 70c and typically only stay around 60c when gaming. A huge improvement over my 3060 ti where the gb of Vram was holding me back at 1440p. The coil whine however was annoying at full loads, however with a -75 undervolt offset, it was hardly noticeable anymore. Love this card

Got 7350 in Steel Nomad after undervolt and overclock. Runs decently cool. Runs almost all of my games at 100+ fps 1440p ultra settings. (Only exception being AoC). Would use again if I had to build a new PC.

FSR4 is amazing compared to FSR3. This heavy GPU comes with a support for holding it, much appreciated from Sapphire. I had the foam padding to prevent the heatsink from bending, no problem to install it. The temperature are very low, great performance. Got lucky to buy it at a decent price.

Cheapest of the 9070 XT variants, good temps after as slight undervolt and overclock. No issues after installation. great performance.
Waiting for FSR 4 to be utilised on more games

Oh, the unwanted child. I wasn't originally planning on changing GPUs initially, but having seen this at a relatively okay price (and with the looming threat of tariffs jacking its price up), I decided to pull the trigger, even if I was a bit skeptical due to the memory temperature issues noted in a couple reviews. Nope, worked beautifully out of the box, and I'm not expecting much of an issue; I've only had AMD GPUs and none really gave me trouble. Important to note that though later shipments come with foam padding to prevent the heatsink from tilting or bending, mine did not, and yet memory temperatures seem fine as per the readings on HWiNFO.

Bought for a total of $808.55 USD from BitWorks.io, was a lil skeptical but hey its in my hands now.
Nice beefy cooler temps under 50C idle and around 60-65C while in game.
Essentially just 4080 but red.
Also FSR 4 is niceeee.

I managed to get this from Overclockers UK for £650. For a base model, this card is extremely impressive. In Marvel Rivals at 4K, low settings, FSR 4 performance, this card peaked at 3.16 GHz, drawing a maximum of 306 W and averaging 120 FPS over about five hours of playtime according to Adrenaline. VRAM usage also peaked at 13 GB. The core temp hit a peak of 62 C, the memory peaked at 84 C, the hotspot temperature peaked at 81 C, and the fans only ramped up to 33% (1372 RPM).
This card runs cool and quiet, though that's not surprising considering the size of it. For a 304 W GPU, I think they might have gone a tad overboard on the cooler. Its size also meant I was just barely able to fit this thing into my Fractal Design Era 2.
In terms of software, the Adrenaline app is pretty good, and I prefer it to the NVIDIA app (which itself was a big upgrade over GeForce Experience). It has all the stuff you'd expect, most of which I'll never use, but it makes driver maintenance easy enough to be worth installing.
If you're in the market for a 9070 XT, this is a solid option and I can recommend it.
Good card but msrp is dead.

I can not begin to explain how much I love this thing. I will continue to do some more benchmarking on other games just to push it to its limits. Can run anything at 1440p max settings and from what I hear it's really good at 4k aswell. If you can find it anywhere near msrp (or even about $100 more given the current market) GET IT!!!!
amazing max 1440p card

comments: Liking this GPU for my 3d rendering. Sure, it's a few years old, but still good for my use
Works great, great graphics hooked to a 50" 120hz tv

Went on a sale for ~$260 and at that price it's pretty good. I play on 1080P and am able to run The Last of Us Part 1 at ~120 fps with medium/high settings and DLSS. The hottest I've ever seen it get is 65 degrees. I do recommend spending a bit more money to get an AMD card though.

I chose this GPU for my first build, specifically to handle photo editing in Lightroom and Photoshop, as well as some 4K video editing. So far, it’s been a solid performer across the board. With 12GB of GDDR6 VRAM, this GPU offers plenty of memory for handling high-resolution images and complex editing tasks without slowing down. In Lightroom and Photoshop, everything runs smoothly—even when working with large files and multiple layers. The GPU acceleration in these programs really benefits from the RTX 3060’s power, making the editing process faster and more efficient. The dual-fan design of the Ventus 2X keeps the card cool under load, and I haven’t noticed any significant noise during operation. It’s a great option if you’re looking for a well-rounded and budget-friendly GPU that can handle creative tasks like photo and video editing without breaking the bank.
i just I recommend a radeon one..
Solid graphics card. Has taken everything I've thrown at it so far and temps run smoothly. Was cheaper than the 8gb version when I ordered everything and so far it's worked well!
Card was smaller than I thought, fit perfectly in my case and its delivering very well, 0 complaints here.
Keeps quite cool, good performance for price.

Bought it with the whole intention of upgrading when the 40 series cards come down in price a bit. Its a solid card for a solid price. Not looked into overclocking cos I don't fancy breaking it. Overall perfect card if you're in the same boat as me and intend to wait for prices to drop. Makes absolutely no noise.
Looks good, decent price, runs quiet, enough for basically all modern titles at 1080p. What more could you ask for?

name: ASRock Challenger D Radeon RX 6600 8 GB Video Card
comments: very good for mid range 1080p
Impressive. handles max 1080p graphics really well.
Works great with my Linux build.
Works great, but I don't play many recent AAA titles. For me, 1080p60 is just fine...!
It’s a super solid pick for the price range and REALLY delivers. This card doesn't raise a fuss at anything 1080 I’ve thrown at it so far while getting 60+ fps. And, as a bonus, looks cool.

Solid GPU. The quality of this GPU is about at the level of an rtx 2070 when comparing to the Nvidia side of things. It may not be top of the line, but you get the best value for the money you pay compared to pretty much every other GPU

I got this only because I wanted to support multiple (potential) 4k 120+ Hz monitors and do very light gaming. The only game I ever play is Grid 2, and I'm getting 4k 60 fps (min) on Ultra and 100 fps (min) on High settings. Paired with a Ryzen 7 9700x, since my usage is really CPU heavy (non-gaming). Other than that, stays cool and quiet for the most part.
Best value graphics card out there in this price range. Chews through games and renders, is power efficient, plus doesn't look half bad.

(Overclocked to 2400 mz Min 2500 mz Max): Pretty good 1080p GPU overall. Seems to consistently get over 60fps (60hz monitor) in Fallout 4 on 1080p High. It also gets around 40fps in BeamNG on West Coast map in the Bastion with traffic and around 50 - 55 without traffic (See images for settings) Overall would recommend for budget builds.
The 6600 is a budget king!

name: Gigabyte GAMING OC Radeon RX 7800 XT 16 GB Video Card
comments: I was planning to buy it two weeks ago when the price was £435, but I went on holiday with my family for a week and wouldn’t have been around to collect it. Of course, when I came back, the price had skyrocketed. Luckily, I managed to find one for £480. When I saw the new price, I debated getting the 7700 XT, but I ultimately stuck with the 7800 XT, and I’m glad I did. I’m able to play Oblivion on high settings with ray tracing enabled, at 1440p, and I get around 60 FPS. I’m using an HDMI cable, which isn’t ideal, but it’s what I’ve got for now. Coming from a PS5 and only playing on consoles, it’s a real treat to experience high FPS and beautiful graphics on PC.
Playing in 1080p and can run most games in max settings !
Solid card and got a copy of MHW with it for free.
Absolutely amazing GPU for the price i got it. If you find it for around my price, snipe it before anyone else can.
Great performance!! gets a little bit loud, but the cooling is great so you can set the fan curve very low. barely reaches over 60°C overall in gaming and the Hotspot stays around 80°C max.
For 500 Bucks you can game every game in 1440p High easily and often even in 4k, great choice! The Cooler makes it good for OC, so make sure to do that for p e r f e c t performance
Just the GOAT for this price range. No questions asked.
Has been amazing, it has a duel bios, with a silent one, and an OC bios. I keep mine on OC because I don't mind noise too much. It is still very quiet with the OC bios.

In my country (The Netherlands) this is pretty much the only card with 16 GB of VRAM for 500 euros or less. I'm happy with it's performance. Out of the box, the fans spin like crazy and makes a lot of noise. I also noticed quite significant coil whine. After undervolting the GPU it is able to run a lot cooler and more efficient without a noticeable decrease in performance, the coil whine also reduced.
I recommend this product, and recommend buyers to experience with undervolting has it improved my experience with this card a lot.

A little place holder until either a 9070xt or 5080 is bought. It's a good card and performs well at 1440p in the games I play like RDR2, Forza, Hogwarts, Madden 25 & The Witcher 3. the temps are fine at around 60-65c in my setup however the fans can be loud under certain loads. I've set mine under my fan curve software to between 30-60% which is fine. Along with the other cooling within the case, I can get the above temps, and it's virtually silent to quietly running. If you struggle with airflow, this can get loud at +70% fan speed.

name: Asus PRIME OC GeForce RTX 5070 12 GB Video Card
comments: A FANTASTIC upgrade from the RTX 3070 Ti. The gpu usage in games went down by a lot (allowing for higher settings), with my 1440p monitor. The graphics card is running much cooler and quieter too. Great for gamers, game development, and video editing.

name: NVIDIA Founders Edition GeForce RTX 5090 32 GB Video Card
comments:
If I weren't able to sell my Gigabyte Master 4090, for what I paid ($1800) AND Nvidia's "priority access" then I'd never consider buying it.
Cons:
Terrible drivers (and "Nvidia App") that keep me at the launch version. Clearly, Nvidia's software devs are preoccupied with AI and enterprise suites to give a damn about consumers and professionals.
Terrible coil whine, regardless of V-sync settings, which speaks volumes considering the last two gens (4090 & 3090) were fine. Obviously, they rushed the final QA and/or didn't care as they figured professionals will store these far away in steel cases.
12VHPWR design flaws and blatant disregard for consumer safety to the point of gaslighting and out-right lies. Luckily, I haven't had issues over the 2 years owning an AIB 4090. However, I'm not taking chances with this iteration by undervolting and ensuring adequate airflow over the connector.
Manufacturing blemishes on the grills and connector side panel. My nearly 5 year old RTX 3090 is in pristine condition, so paying $2k+ makes this inexcusable...
============
Positive(s):
32 GB GDDR7.
20-30% uplift @ 5% cost difference (albeit, I overpaid for my 4090 🤷‍♂️)
2-slot design
Overall build quality, aesthetic, and packaging
Great (and great-looking) card, if you can get it at MSRP - which I was only able to due to sheer luck.
Great GPU, works really well with SFF cases, no noticeable coil whine on my unit.

Coil whine is a bit scary but honestly, it's the best card out there for raw performance (Honestly overkill for 99% of games). Cooling solution is nice!
Minus points for the connector, should have been revised how this thing gets its power and at the very least had a solution to monitor each pin.

name: Gigabyte GAMING OC GeForce RTX 5070 Ti 16 GB Video Card
comments: Waited about a year to upgrade -- read my story above. The price of this thing is too expansive and it's essentially a 4080/ 4080 Super with lower power draw and a little cheaper with more AI capability. It's quiet and it's powerful. I opted to use Nvidia's 12v-2x6 adapter instead of my 12vhpwr adapter due to all the controversy. I don't want to buy ANOTHER PSU. No issues so far. Fingers crossed. With the lack of PhysX support, I had to uninstall 2 metro games and 3 batman games. I don't play them either way.
Great GPU got this for $2000 had to do an update in GIGABYTE Control Centre to get the rgb working now it looks very nice
lined up outside of micro center for this, got it for close to msrp

name: Gigabyte GAMING OC Radeon RX 9070 XT 16 GB Video Card
comments:
This was the purchase that triggered the build. I think I bagged the last 9070xt in the UK on launch day!
Great GPU, and out of the box it's very quiet. 3D Mark scores are above average for the 9070xt. I ended up underclocking it a bit to save on power. I managed to get a -40mV undervolt combined with a -500MHz underclock and -10% power limit and it runs very cool and quiet, and I'm still getting average 3D mark scores!
Other 9070xt models can get a better undervolt, I maybe didn't win the silicon lottery, but its still an impressive display for a lower-end 9070xt model.
Note that this model requires THREE PCIe 8-pin connectors. My PSU had exactly three, but two of the connectors are daisy chained. THIS IS OKAY! I've had zero issues with the daisy chained PCIe connector since installation, and it's been through a lot of stress tests.
BEWARE GIGABYTE CONTROL CENTER!
Because I have a Gigabyte motherboard and a Gigabyte GPU, I downloaded Gigabyte Control Center to control the RGB. This works fine, but one of the other tools (I think maybe the performance tool plugin?) took control of the fan curve, which was ATTROCIOUS. The card's sweet spot for temperature is around 75°C, and at that temperature Gigabyte's default fan curve puts the fans at 100%, which is abour 4000RPM. It's LOUD. Once I uninstalled the fan control tools, the default fan curve is infinitely quieter.
The other fan curves for CPU and case fans/pumps are all editable in the BIOS. A bit inconvenient, but the Gigabyte Control Center app doesn't provide any additional functionality.

Got this at launch for Gigabyte's standard price of 730. I'd rather pay MSRP, but we all know that's a thing of the past. At least I didn't have to pay scalper prices.
My other PC has a 7900xtx in it and I would say that this GPU keeps up with it well. With ray tracing enabled it seems to do a little better in the games that I play. I personally don't care for ray tracing, but I know that many do. In my ITX case the card runs at 60 under a load with the hot spot just breaking 80.
All in all I'm very happy with the performance for the price I paid.

Incredible GPU for 1440p and even 4K gaming. Runs cool, stays quiet, and delivers outstanding performance. Works well with the Ryzen 5 7600, though upgrading to a higher-end CPU would further unleash its full potential.

This thing is pretty sweet. I camped out for the first time in my life on launch day. I got it for MSRP and it's a massive improvement from what I had before. Temps seem reasonable and it looks to be built pretty well too. It is one of the OC variants so I've seen it drawing 350w+.

name: Gigabyte WINDFORCE OC GeForce RTX 4060 8 GB Video Card
comments: Not the greatest aesthetics, but the cheapest 4060 available and 2x HDMI. Runs quite cool (and silent) in my experience.
The RTX 4060 is a mid-tier GPU. It offers excellent performance for 1080p gaming and respectable results at 1440p, especially in titles with DLSS 3 support.
Solid card for 1080p gaming, 3D Mark scores for 4060 were slightly above average. I take off 1 star because I think it's a bit overpriced for a 1080p card.
Not the best price to performance, but it gets the job done for somebody who wants an Nvidia GPU.

Most YouTubers and online reviewers that I watch/read from say this card is a disappointment for 1080p gamers, but I beg to differ. I am not comparing it against an AMD card because this is my first PC
I upgraded from a GTX 1660Ti laptop version to this RTX 4060 desktop, and the performance difference is INSANE. I can play Helldivers 2 at 1080p Medium-High Graphic Settings at 120 FPS no issue, Fortnite on DX12 with High settings at 144FPS (without ray-tracing) and 280-300fps on the performance mode. Rocket league is a stable 240 fps at max settings (with a maximum of 300fps from my experience), Minecraft: Java Edition at max240 fps with an avg of 140-180fps with 16 render chunks, with Sodium and all those fabric mods installed, and at around 90-120 fps with shaders at that same render distance.
All those FPS listings above was while the card was remaining under an 80C temp. I average about 73-78C on most games. Highest I've gone is 83C on CS2 at around 300 FPS on High settings. I highly recommend this card to any budget builder that can afford this in their budget if possible. I would personally recommend this over the 3060 (8 or 12GB version) because of the lower power consumption while remaining the same performance.
If you want a 12 GB card that badly, I recommend looking at GPUs rated for 1440p rather than 1080p. Such as:
RX 6750XT
RX 6700XT
RX 7700XT
RTX 4070
RTX 4070 Super
had this running in my self build for one year now and now problems so far.

With the controversy surrounding this card, it performs very well and can give very high frame rates, not to mention it has dlss3 and 3 gen rt cores, it does get a little hot as it hit 69c when running time spy. This is due to the stock fan curve being optimized for acoustics and not performance. But it never gets that hot when playing games or browsing and other stuff like that. Overall this is a good gpu for the price and can run any competitive game at a high frame rate.

Great gpu can run many triple a titles ate 60+ frames with not much frame drop but does come with les vram than the 3060 so kinda of a downgrade but comes with great OC capabilities to be able to compare with many newer gpus on the market
Nice graphics card for the price, low profile and looks good too.

name: Sapphire PULSE Radeon RX 7800 XT 16 GB Video Card
comments: An absolute beast of a card! Chews through everything I have at UWQHD with a steady 100 fps at high settings and 60 at max. This was the cheapest model at the time, and it truly delivers
Great GPU for my 1440p/180hz monitor, does not break a sweat running games, and barely gets hot, especially with bottom intake fans
fantastic card at 1440p great price to performance especially since i dont use blender so i dont really super need an nvidia card and the vram is perfect
GPU sag was the only problem but very easy to fix. Two fan configuration not really ideal but this was the only one at the time. It does its job very well so i would say i’m happy with it. 9/10

Powerful card for the price, I got it for 480 on Amazon. Careful when overclock the vram because it crashes the system. If you starve it for voltage your game will crash. Other than that it had no issue
absurdly good gpu would recommend

If you're not interested in Ray Tracing at it's current state like me, this card is really good value over it's NVIDIA counterparts. There's lots of potential to undervolt and overclock this card, which can put it right up there with the 4070 ti. Having 16 GB of VRAM at this price point is a great bonus too.
Despite being a 2 fan model, this cooling solution still makes the card run nice and cool.
Big card. strong card. nicely priced card. good card
I was a bit sceptical of the 2 fan cooling system. Turns out it does the job very well, and it's a beast.

Absolute beast of a GPU. Runs every game I throw at it at 100+ fps on max settings at 1080p. Surprisingly quiet for being only a dual fan card and the temps are great as well (never above 40°C.) Video editing performance with DaVinci Resolve is also amazing. The red and black color scheme is very sleek and nice looking. I appreciate it not being insanely long like some other 7800 XT models and also I love the box the card comes in, it just looks so good. Highly recommend it to anyone looking for a €500 - €600 GPU and doesn't use Blender (Nvidia absolutely destroys AMD in Blender.)

name: Gigabyte GAMING OC Radeon RX 7700 XT 12 GB Video Card
comments: Most expensive part of the build, but it will probably end up being its Achilles heel down the road. At 1080p this is an absolute beast that will chomp down pretty much anything I throw at it (within reason). However, seeing new games already have the 7700XT below recommended settings worries me for how future proof it'll really be. It somewhat bums me that I had to buy during such a terrible market; I would've appreciated getting a 9070XT or 5060ti instead if either card was reasonably priced. However, for now, it works with everything on 1080p, even heavy ray tracing, so I can't really complain. It's pretty loud, but the cooling is super efficient and I've never seen it go above 60°C. Overclocking speeds are above what's advertised, which is dope.

I'd have given this a 2/5, but I managed to find a solution.
At first the factory OC was way too much and ALWAYS crashed in any game. I'd be playing for like 10 minutes and then, without fail, it would freeze and then crash. Very annoying.
The solution? Just use Adrenalin to underclock it. My max clock is set at 2395 MHz with 1150 mV.
After that it works AMAZING. I can play most games at max settings in 1080p and basically anything in High 1080p. I'd recommend it more if that first issue wasn't present.
Such a nice looking graphics card, I love the exposed copper piping, LED logo, and just the overall built quality. Great for 1440p

Looks sleek and minimalistic. Performs well at the price point. Cools pretty adequately. It could work spectacularly in 1440p but I've got it for 240hz 1080p gaming and it shreds through loads of games. Very nice.
Better than the 4060ti for around the same price. You really can’t do better than a 7700XT. The Gigabyte Gaming GPU models are my favorite.
Great GPU. The 7700XT is amazing for 1440P gaming able to play most games max settings.
it is amazing and it is so good compared to my old rtx 3050 and the software is amazing
She's a great card! Very cool, and does an awesome job in 1080p. FSR3 makes her even better now! She'll tear Cyberpunk up!
Good build quality card, and it looks very clean. Maybe not the best time to pick up the rx 7700xt considering it's price point compared to last gen cheaper AMD cards, like the RX 6800.

name: PNY VCNRTX6000ADA-PB RTX 6000 Ada Generation 48 GB Video Card
comments: Amazing card which I got greatly discounted from a local merchant.

name: Asus TUF GAMING OC GeForce RTX 5080 16 GB Video Card
comments: An absolute powerhouse that can play any game I want at 4k. Ray tracing, say less. A bit pricey, but after getting it, so worth it.
Blew my expectations out of the water. Frame gen is insane, but isn't even necessary with this card. If you can get one at a reasonable price, DO IT!!!

These are expensive, even without the current scalping problems. But the price is worth it. The card is overbuilt to provide plenty of room for overclocking if that is your thing. Even running out of the box, this card runs cool and is powerful. I am able to run Cyberpunk 2077 at on an ultrawide 2K monitor with max settings and DLSS while maintaining 90-100FPS. name: Gigabyte WINDFORCE OC GeForce RTX 4070 12 GB Video Card

A very good graphics card, But i would suggest you get the RX 7900 GRE for the same price but overall very good graphics good and has not failed me.
Vool thing overrated bit okay and does the job

The fact that this card has the performance that it has, which is about equivalent to a 3080-12GB, at about half the wattage, is crazy. I would have wished for 16GB on this card, considering the 7800XT has 16 :/ But still, totally worth.
Able to play games on it. 5 stars

A beast of a card. It runs everything I've used at max settings and has never gone above 60 degrees!
Good 1440p card. Have not ran anything crazy yet

I wanted something that would be suitable to use for 1440p when I upgrade the display, and my hope is that this card will be able to keep up with new releases several years down the line, perhaps using DLSS if necessary.
It doesn't come with any kind of anti-sag bracket, so I bought an adjustable pole support on Amazon for $15.

The RTX 4070 is such a great card for 1080p/1440p (and even 4k) gaming. Prices have come down with the 4000 series Super refreshes and I think that makes them even more enticing - especially if you can find them under $550 (which is happening more and more)
This Gigabyte card is awesome. I've personally got a Zotac Twin Edge 4070 and the sound profile is a night and day difference. This Gigabyte card is extremely quite even when the fans spin up to 70%. Finally, the cooling solution does work phenomenally well. The card has never exceeded the mid 60s, and it consistently runs about 750 MHz over stock clock speeds (1,920MHz -> 2,668MHz)

name: Gigabyte GAMING OC Radeon RX 7600 XT 16 GB Video Card
comments: This looks great and works great. It can run most not insanely demanding games in 1440p high without a problem. Got it for only 315 which is insane price to performance but do not buy for over 400 if it is selling for that much.
The extra VRAM is really nice
Solid GPU for its price, love the overabundance of VRAM as well, makes me feel safe knowing any game won't be bottlenecked by it!
good card:)

Managed to overclock it to 3200Mhz. Stays surprising cool considering this case has one 92mm exhaust fan, it helps that it is severely bottlenecked by the cpu and struggles to run at full use in real world scenarios. at max rpm, the fans are extremely loud, beyond gaming laptop levels, but it rarely gets hot enough for the fans to spin up.

name: Gigabyte WINDFORCE OC GeForce RTX 4070 SUPER 12 GB Video Card
comments: A very powerful and sleek card in my opinion.

Get it while it lasts. Seems this model is getting lower and lower on stock since the 50 series releases. I went with the Super instead of Ti Super. The extreme increase in cost didn't make sense to me for the claimed performance. Perhaps if you go for 4k gaming. I like to run at 1440. This for me is perfect price point for monitor/GPU combo for my eyes. You really aren't going to benefit from more pixel unless you get a 40+ inch monitor. 1440 is plenty sharp for my 34" ultra wide.
Most games I run hit over 120 FPS.
Great build quality and thermals, stays under 30 on idle and doesn't even crack 50 under load. Smaller than I expected too.
Amazing GPU that absolutely shreds at 1440p with above 120hz framerates in almost every game on ultra settings and runs incredibly cool.
Is expensive but i can play everything i want so w
fans are kind of loud but it is well under load even in itx builds
Good 1440p card, waiting for price drops though from MSRP.
Good cooling and incredible performance for 1080p and 1440p gaming.
Could look a bit nicer but it works amazing!

I've been running this card using DSR 4k and DSDLR 1440P for 2 months now along side a Ryzen 5 7600X and the performance is great for the $600 US price tag. The card looks great and cooling is great, not sure if its the card itself, the amount of fans I have, or both working together, but temps haven't gone over 60 degrees Celsius after hours of gaming at max load.`

Intel is doing something right. Card runs very well and cool. No issues with drivers. Great buy considering the crazy market. Surprising thing is it runs better than my old 1080ti @ 1440p.

Well, it’s been a wild couple of months for the GPU market, again. The new generation of cards is being massively gouged, and the old generation is shooting up in price. So, how does my latest acquisition hold up? Pretty well, to put it plainly. My B580 was on backorder since the end of 2024, and I had it in hand a month later for Intel’s suggested retail price. I’ve always liked slightly odd peripherals, and Intel’s previous forays into the GPU market have certainly been awkward.
On the hardware side, it ticks all the boxes for decent longevity. The industrial design of the shell is perennial—a black plastic rectangle bereft of aggressive angular lines, rainbow LEDs, or the military foot-locker aesthetic board partners seem to love. The specs are great for the price—trading blows with the 4060 Ti and 7600 XT. Best of all, the thermals and potential for overclocking have been solid.
Intel’s software is Radeon-tier, in my opinion. A little better organized than AMD’s offerings, but with fewer features. Some options aren’t explained clearly, and the ability to reduce the card’s voltage below stock settings just doesn’t exist. A lot of third-party tuning software (such as Afterburner) also struggles with Intel’s architecture.
“Radeon-like” sums up much of the Battlemage experience, as there’s significant overlap between the brands. Vulkan support isn’t just optional for this card—it’s preferable. Linux support shouldn’t be a matter of if but when. And unless XeSS catches on in more games, FSR 3.1 is the best way to upscale most titles.
With Intel’s limited track record in the dedicated graphics business, it’s hard to say exactly how well this card will age. But I think it’s a great deal for the tumultuous present.

What a beast. Not much more to say. Runs all my games at 1440p max settings (no ray tracing) at 144fps or more. highest temps ive seen so far are 57C on the gpu and 83 hotspot. Fans can get a little noisy but with a custom fan curve its barely noticable. Looks great too in a more minimal build.

It's a fantastic GPU. To put this into perspective for you, the last graphics card I ever actually saw and touched with my own eyes and hands was when I was in middle school and my dad bought a GeForce 6600 GT in 2004. Now, if you don't know what a gpu from 2004 looks and feels like, google that and then compare it to this.
It's like watching an M1 Abrams roll up on Godzilla.
The thing weighs a ton. I'm pretty sure that besides the case and PSU, it's the heaviest piece of equipment I bought for the entire build. This isn't a negative thing for me though. I like the bulk. I like the design. I like the lit up XFX on the side. It came with a Z-bar for support, and it is needed. Once installed there is no give on the card, it feels very supported. My only gripe is the little silver bracket that's included for the Z-bar installation has a very weak adhesive on it. It liked to slide while I was trying to screw in the 4 support screws, so I had to continually remove the card to readjust the bracket. A nice pain in the ***, but overall it doesn't effect the quality of the card.
It runs everything I want flawlessly, doesn't get too hot, and I don't hear any whine or odd sounds from it. I'm very happy with the purchase and I will be buying XFX products again.

name: Sapphire NITRO+ Radeon RX 7900 XTX 24 GB Video Card
comments:
I really prefer the Nitro+ over all other version of the 7900 XTX. It looks great and performs unbeleiveable good in cooling and overclocking. Unfortunally i put it under water... In the beginning the build was planned with an alphacool core waterblock but unfortunenatly its EOL. So i had to switch to a bykski one. First i was a little suspicious of them but the block turns out to be very well made and its performing very good. I put an Hineywell ptm on the die and pink thermal putty on evrything else. It runs at 3180Mhz with 2800Mhz on the memory.
And then i flashed the Asrock aqua OC bios on the card, which made it possible to install an Asrock program to make it an extrem OC bios. This took the power limit from 460W to 560W. Big jump. That was the last step i needed to get to No. 1 in Time Spy Extreme, Speedway and Port Royal in Germany and top 10 global. Only downside is that the first HDMI port is not working anymore because the Asrock Aqua has a Displayport at that spot.

Love/hate relationship with Relive, but I still use for ease of use when taking screenshots/clips. Still have some driver crashes occasionally. Also runs kinda hot (even in old build). Have some new pads and PTM7950 to apply, but haven't gotten around to doing yet.

It's my first AMD card and I didn't want to spend €2000 on the graphics card alone, so I opted for the 7900 XTX.
So far I haven't noticed anything negative except for the LED bar, which flickers if you don't check "use external control" in the Trixx software.
Probably fixable by AMD adjusting the driver, but I'm not sure.

It's a been a long while since I have used an AMD card. I am very happy with this card for what it is. I am also very impressed with Sapphire as an AIB. The ARGB port is a brilliant way to ensure compatibility with other software vendors rgb implementations without introducing any additional overhead from plugins/additional applications. The fan header is cool, though I preferred to use my motherboards fan header so I could control the curve with fan control I also love the look of this card. My only gripe is that its not quite powerful another to drive my 57" G9. I have to scale back setting and crank up FSR quite a bit to get decent framerate. However, I assumed this going and will address with a 5090 when they are readily available. Not a fault of this card, and I think you can get a great experience on a 4k display.

Value 10/10 Looks 10/10 Temps ~70C under load Fan noise 6/10
Even at full price the card is a good deal compared to the rtx 5070 given that there is no change to get those at msrp.
The card looks amazing and has a really sturdy high quality feel. They dont skimp on material - the metal sheet around is about half a centimeter thick steel, the plastic bit on the light bar is thick. The light bar is bright and has all the color options you could want.
Temps stay reasonable and well under max range when under extended medium-high loads. It uses 3 8 pin power connectors, to avoid hotspots at the cable connections its best to use good cables/extensions and make sure the PSU has the slots.
The max noise on all of the fans on my build are under 35 db, I don't know why I bothered because the card itself produces about 56 db at 75% fan speed, which is well audible if the pc sits on the desk.
An absolute beast of a card in the benchmarks I've run. Couldn't be happier with upgrading to this from my 2060 Super.

What an amazing job AMD did with this card, only to be topped by Sapphire’s incredible cooling solution. I used the Adrenaline software to lockthe clock to minimum 2500Mhz and maximum 2600Mhz, while giving +15% power limit and undervolting it to 1120mV. This ensures stable, high performance because it’s not spiking to reach a very high clock and then dropping because of thermal throttle, while also shredding the wattage from 400-450w in games to 250-280w. For reference, in Division 2 (my main game), I pull 350 FPS in Countdown, with the temps being 55-58c, consuming 250-280w, with the fan being inaudible at 700-900RPM.
Truly a remarkable piece of engineering.

Ended up opting for the NITRO+ after trying the Asrock Phantom Gaming and Sapphire Pulse. The Asrock got returned after reading many reviews abotu eventual thermal issues. The Pulse got returned when the NITRO+ price dropped to the same amount. Love this card. Its beefy, quiet, and cool. Best 7900 XTX out there not on water.
LOVE LOVE LOVE this GPU!!! I get over 100 fps 4k gaming in Tarkov on medium like settings!

Runs surprisingly quiet under load and runs anything I want at max settings without problems. It even allows me to run without FSR frame generation or upscaling. Driver compatibility for Linux is unbeaten atm for AMD, so this card was a no brainer. Also one of the best looking GPUs I’ve seen out there. Also clocks really high with not much of an overclock. A beast of a GPU

name: Sapphire PULSE Radeon RX 9070 16 GB Video Card

As far as i know high memory temp is normal for the 9070 series. If it worries you for longevity you might want to increase the fan speed. Which is something i might do aswell.
I was able to get it at the dutch msrp, currently the card is 100euro's more expensive than msrp. I'd say it's a good buy at msrp any higher is really up to you to decide.
Had a RX 6600 before, all i can say it is a very big performance difference.

Got it at MSRP price and, for that price, it is a bargain. Unfortunately scalpers are scalping now. Huge performance increase over my 3070 (which now lives in my other half deskop for 3D modeling), absolute silence, low temps and will not require to change my PSU.
The compact form factor is also very nice to have in the case to improve airflow
AMD, just release the ROCm update now! :) my toying with ollama is now suspended. Darn.

name: ASRock Steel Legend Radeon RX 9070 XT 16 GB Video Card
comments:
Wasn’t fussed what 9070xt I got, as long as it wasn’t more than $1139 which was the lowest they could be had for here. Any higher and I couldn’t justify it, especially with the 9070 being a good option.

Managed to nab at listing price ($670).
Very impressive so far, though my Linux drivers (kernel: 6.13.7-200.nobara.fc41.x86_64) are apparently a little out-dated? I noticed some really strange display glitching (with color accuracy: prefer accuracy) and VRAM allocation catastrophes in some games (MHWilds). 16GB is weirdly not enough for 4K games. My take is that, for <=$700, this is the best value card on the market, regardless of what people say. Adrenalin pleaseee, I can't even toggle FSR4 because of it.

name: NVIDIA Founders Edition GeForce RTX 3060 Ti 8 GB Video Card
comments: I might not reach 1440p with Ultra settings, high ray tracing, and all that, but for what it cost, it’s amazing—especially considering how well-built it is.

name: Sapphire PULSE Radeon RX 7600 XT 16 GB Video Card
comments: I've got to say I am very impressed with this card. It gets a lot of flak from rich youtubers and reviewers online, but its a solid card. I play primarily AAA titles, old and new. I'm not much of an E sport gamer so I don't care all that much about fps. This card is able to play games like RDR2, the Tomb Raider reboots, and TLOU1 at 1440P max settings with 60FPS. For the very demanding games like TLOU1 you do need frame gen to keep that 60FPS stable but for everything else I mentioned and games similar to it, it chews through them at native 1440 just fine. I did notice some FPS fluctuation in Tomb Raider 2013, but its most likely due to that games PC port not being all that optimized being over a decade old. The big kicker on this card is the large 16GB memory buffer, it severely helps at 1440P and is the reason why its even able to game at that higher resolution. Despite what folks say, its not useless. Its got about a 288GB memory bandwidth which is on the higher side for the 128 bit bus and is more than adequate for 1440P gaming. Again, I see no issues and got the card for a bit more than an RTX 4060 and I'm loving it. Temps are good, the fans nice and quiet, the card has good thermals, and it's just about 2 slots so it fits perfectly into my SFF console sized case. At MSRP for 30 bucks more than an NVIDIA 4060 the card is incredible value and its awesome that you can get into high fidelity 1440P gaming for sub 350 bucks
Excellent for 1080p but struggles a bit on 1440p. Otherwise pretty cheap for a 16gb gpu.

But... I've been playing Cyberpunk, and couldn't resist seeing how it would handle a ray tracing workload. 4k ulta, no ray-tracing runs at 120 FPS without a hitch. With the lightest rtx settings the performance drops to ~60 FPS, even at 1440. 60 is definitely playable in most situations, but I have a VA monitor and anything under 100 gets awfully smeary.
It does what I wanted it to do well. It's a bit frustrating that ray tracing is beyond the 7900's reach, but I don't think there's a card on the market for under 1000 USD that would do better (this card may cost more than that now). I know I made some other choices (like a 4k VA monitor) which also make the ray-tracing dream harder to realize. At the same time I have to admit I'm a bit bummed. I'm not getting the "real" shadows and seeing reflections. I want it all, I just don't want to spend double the rest of my components to get it. It's not really this card's fault--The NVIDIA marketing machine worked. I'm tempted to drop more than a few month's rent on some silicon that will be obsolete in a few years just so some grass has a shadow in a part of the screen I'm barely looking at

The Sapphire PULSE 7900 XT OC performs beyond what I expected since I came from being an RTX 3060 laptop user. Also, I was interested in overclocking, so I went to Adrenalin and tuned several settings:
[Fan Tuning]:
Zero RPM: Disabled
Advanced Control: Enabled
[GPU Tuning]:
Advanced Control: Enabled
Min Frequency: 500
Max Frequency: 3100
Voltage: 990
[Power Tuning]:
Power Limit: 15%
[VRAM Tuning]:
Memory Timing: Fast Timing
Advanced Control: Enabled
Max Frequency: 2568
After months of constant playing (1440p & 240Hz), I haven’t faced any huge issues, and the 7900 XT has been working great and better after tuning. I optimized the GPU fans to be at 65% RPM when the GPU hotspot temperature reached 75 Celsius to ease the heat and noise level. I never saw the temperature go beyond 80, usually around 75 Celsius at best. So, most of the time, the 7900 XT stays silent and doesn’t consume much power, although it does get somewhat loud and power-hungry (100% ~ 365 watts) on GPU-heavy games (7DTD and Space Marine 2.) The 7900 XT did create coil whines at first, but over time, it disappeared. Overall, I am pretty satisfied with my purchase.

name: PowerColor RX 7900 XT 20G Radeon RX 7900 XT 20 GB Video Card
comments: great card, runs 1440p on high settings and 20 VRAM is great future proofing

Got this card for $700 at Microcenter, and at that price the 7900XT is a pretty decent buy for the performance. However, there definitely are a few issues I have with card, starting with a reference model specific issue regarding memory junction temperatures; If the GPU core temperature is 60C, the memory junction temp is usually at 84C, which is a 24C delta between the two. This drastic difference in temperature seems to be a flaw with the reference designs only, and so should be solved with AIB models.
Although the total board power was 315W max as expected, I found that the card also tried to boost all the way to 2900MHz, which is 500MHz past the advertised boost clock! Under this behavior the "GPU power maximum" reading in HWinfo64 could reach all the way to 500W, which was just unsettling. What compounds this issue is the fact that the card has very bad coil whine when it tries to boost to such high clocks. And so to optimize the card I simply limited the clock to 2400MHz, increased the memory clock to 2714MHz, increased the power limit to +15%, and undervolted it to 1030mV. With these settings, I only lost 5% of the stock performance while consuming a lot less power on average (315W down to sub-250W) and greatly silenced the coil whine. If the card shipped like this at stock I would have probably given it 5 stars with the only caveat being the high but not dangerous memory junction temperatures.

Even finished a speedway run at +450 MHZ but was far from stable at that range. Temps at +375 MHZ were peaking at 70C so (and I'm new to overclocking so not sure about this) but it seems the limiting factor is probably voltage or power delivery. Didn't want to raise those though; I'm not confident enough for that yet.
Planning on undervolting and overclocking for everyday use now.

name: Gigabyte AORUS ELITE Radeon RX 9070 XT 16 GB Video Card

specs.Part #:
GV-R9070XTAORUS E-16GD
AORUS Radeon RX 9070 XT ELITE 16G
GV-R9070XTAOE-16GD
R9070XTAORUS E 16GD

comments:
This card is one of the few 9070 XTs advertised as reaching 3100 rather than 3060 MHz boost clocks, alongside the ASRock Taichi and some XFX cards. Interestingly, the Aorus and Taichi are also the cheapest 9070 XT flagship cards. With out of the box settings it actually boosted to 3150 MHz. This card has a vapour chamber, dual bios, and uses 3x8pin, so on paper the only downside is that it doesn't use PTM7950.
Cooling is excellent as would be expected from the massive heatsink, and the default fan curve prioritizes lower fan speed over lower temps, with fans not even beginning to spin until the hotspot reaches 50 degrees, and usually spinning at around 1000 rpm (max ~3500) unless temps heavily increase. With a relatively quiet fan curve hot spot temp remains below 65 degrees and VRAM below 75. Running fans at max speed without sharply increasing case fan speeds during benchmarks with overclocked VRAM, speeds over 3300 MHz and +10% power limit the highest temperatures I noticed were 78 degrees on the hot spot and 86 degrees on the VRAM. More than adequate performance given the task and well below thermal limits.
Speculative, but I also suspect that these cards are very aggressively binned, moreso than any other 9070 XT model. At first I noticed that my card was an absolute silicon lottery win, reaching #3 Port Royal, #5 Steel Nomad DX12, and #9 Time Spy Graphics Score on the 3DMark 9070 XT leaderboards. A friend with another Aorus 9070 XT also got relatively high scores, and I saw another example online. I checked the 3DMark leaderboards again and noticed that 5 of the top 10 Time Spy graphics scores were Gigabyte cards, 5 of the top 10 Port Royal scores were Gigabyte cards, and 6 out of the top 10 Steel Nomad scores were Gigabyte cards. With Gigabyte being a second tier AMD AIB, the overrepresentation in benchmark scores, the Aorus being one of the few 3100 MHz cards, and that Gigabyte Gaming OCs seem much more common than Gigabyte Aorus cards, I think it's very possible that Gigabyte is aggressively binning both the GPU chips and VRAM that goes into their Aorus cards.
Got this for $1020 CAD ($710 USD) when "MSRP" models were selling for around $950 CAD. Unless it was confirmed Aorus 9070 XTs are all aggressively binned I would not rate 5 stars if pricing improved on other 9070 XT models, 5070 Tis, or price went up on this card.

name: PowerColor Hellhound OC Radeon RX 9070 XT 16 GB Video Card
comments:
This is an excellent graphics card--certainly the best one to launch in 2025, as far as I'm concerned. I got it on launch day for $750. I'm not pleased with that price, as it's really only worth it at $599, but I needed a GPU to put in a friend's new PC, and I didn't expect prices to normalize any time soon. Had I not been building a PC for a friend, I wouldn't have upgraded from the 6900XT at this price. It's only a 25% performance gain for roughly a 50% premium vs. the used market, and that's not even considering the ridiculous prices it's inflated to as of this review.
That said, the ray-tracing performance in particular is leagues beyond what I had on RDNA2. Monster Hunter Wilds Benchmark runs at >70 FPS average at 4k max settings, highest ray-tracing, and FSR Quality. Avowed and Jedi Survivor give roughly 55-60 FPS experiences at 4k Ultra with high RT and Quality upscaling. FSR4 also looks great in the approximately 5 games it's actually available for months after launch.
On principle, don't buy Nvidia 50-series, buy this instead.

Best purchase of 2025! This card is an absolute beast for 1440p gaming, handling max settings in virtually every game I play. It runs cool, consistently staying under 60°C, and the smart fan feature is a fantastic bonus—when the GPU isn't in use, the fans stop running, keeping things nice and quiet. Highly recommend if you can get one for MSRP!

comments:
It's good enough. 12 GB of VRAM on a 5070-named model is pathetic, but I agree with the PC enthusiasts, like Hardware Unboxed, when they say the 5070 is more like nVidia's X060 models now in all but name. Normally, I wouldn't suggest paying more than MSRP for this, but if you're in the United States as of early April 2025, it's hard to say what the impending tariffs will do to pricing here, plus availability being absolutely awful. I wouldn't recommend a 5070 for anything more than $650 pre-tariffs, but who knows, it could be an insane deal by the time the tariffs are in effect (if they end up affecting the GPU market, there's some rumors that semi-conductors will not be including in the tariffs, I don't know what the hell is going on or going to happen).
The best time in recent history to get a GPU or PC parts in general was around Black Friday 2024 or Summer 2024 (7800X3Ds were $330...). Just know if you're shopping for used graphics cards, the 5070 is comparable to a 4070 Super, give and take a few % depending on the game, so hopefully that advance can at least create a baseline for value you can use.
This particular model of 5070 is bare bones if even visually unimpressive, and if you have the Lancool 207 case, I would suggest a longer 3-fan GPU just for the better aesthetics, but even with just two fans, this GPU's temps are just fine under load, especially in the Lancool 207, which has excellent airflow with two fans running air right on to the GPU from it's vented basement. Running Cinebench R23, the GPU peaked after minutes at 71 Celsius and Monster Hunter Wilds on high settings at 1440p it was around 60 Celsius tops at 120+ FPS. Will update with Cyberpunk later if I remember to run it before it goes to it's eventual owner.
I'd recommend the AMD RX 9070 XT or even an RX 9070 at MSRP before this, but I saw this for $549.99 ($563 after shipping) on Newegg and was able to "Add To Cart" and didn't care to think on it much with how the GPU market, even the used GPU market, is now days.
